Award.AwardTitle: CMG Collaborative Research: Efficient high dimensional Bayesian methods for climate field reconstruction
Award.AbstractNarration:
Paleoclimate reconstructions aim to recreate past climates and are critical in assessing how modern day temperatures (and other climate variables) are anomalous in a millennial context. Most of the methods available in the literature give consolidated estimates of climate variables over the past millennium and beyond. It is widely recognized that changes in climate differ by spatial location; for example, estimated changes in temperature, and variability thereof, between the tropics and the polar regions are different. Obtaining a detailed understanding of such phenomena requires developing methodology for paleoclimate reconstructions that are spatially disaggregated, with uncertainty quantifications of estimated past climate. Spatially disaggregate paleoclimate reconstructions are fundamentally high dimensional statistical problems, with unique challenges imposed by the geosciences context. In particular, paleoclimate reconstruction rely on relating climate variables to proxy variables (such as tree rings, ice cores etc..). The project will lay the theoretical foundation for high dimensional paleoclimate reconstructions using modern day statistical methods. As a concrete application the project will reconstruct global past climates at a spatially disaggregated levels for the past millennium, and also attach confidence statements to these reconstructions. The proposed work entails a collaboration between the mathematical and geo-sciences to solve a scientific problem at the interface of both fields. The methods developed during the project also have broad applications in other fields, such as genomics, where relationships between genes in a high dimensional context are often studied.
Climate field reconstructions are inherently multivariate inference problems (e.g., spatial data on a large grid are required), rely on noisy input data, and are often so high-dimensional that the data dimension is close to or exceeds the sample size, resulting in ill-posed or rank-deficient estimation problems. In this context high dimensional mean and covariance estimation is often at the center of the inferential problem. Furthermore, meaningful solutions to such problems require a reliable knowledge of the uncertainty in estimated model parameters. The need for a rigorous quantification of uncertainties has recently spurred much interest in Bayesian methods for climate reconstruction, usually based on Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling techniques. The latter pose two major issues, as: (1) there is no guarantee that posterior samples are generated from the required distribution (convergence issue); (2) they rely on computationally-heavy algorithms which limit their applicability (efficiency, scalability and applicability). We propose to overcome both limitations by using a flexible but high dimensional Bayesian approach that leads to closed-form solutions for posterior quantities, hence alleviating much of the computational burden. Convergence issues will be addressed first, and dimensionality reduction will subsequently be implemented by exploiting the rich theory of Markov Random fields. The outcome of the theoretical component of the project will be the construction of novel and sound, efficient high-dimensional Bayesian algorithms tailor-made for climate field reconstruction problems. These new statistical tools will then be applied to the reconstruction of global and regional temperature fields from heterogeneous geological proxies (tree rings, ice cores, speleothems, corals, sediments) over the Common Era, and new analysis of instrumental surface temperature and sea-level pressure. The solutions will be accompanied by credible intervals, and promises to yield new insights into natural climate variability at global scales.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this grant was to develop closed-form Bayesian estimators to better estimate climate variability over the modern and pre-instrumental era. 

 

Work led by PI Rajaratnam at Stanford led to many advances in mathematical statistics for developing Bayesian covariance estimation techniques. First, tractable Bayesian inference procedures were developed for sparse inverse covariance estimation outside the rather restrictive class of decomposable graphs [1]. This collaboration allows Bayesian inference methods for Markov random fields to be scalable to the dimensions required for estimating climate variability over the modern and pre-instrumental era. The methods is shown to perform well compared to competing methods.

 

PI Rajaratnam also collaborated on developing tractable and closed form Bayesian inference for estimation and model selection for the class of directed acyclic graphical models [2]. By generalizing the traditional class of priors used in such models, the work yields a flexible framework for undertaking rigorous statistical inference for covariance estimation when the underlying model has conditional independences encoded by a directed acyclic graph. Closed form solutions for the scoring criterion for each model and closed form solutions for covariance and precision matrices are derived. The work is implemented on real datasets to illustrate its efficacy.

 

 

Work led by PI Emile-Geay produced several climate outcomes. A collaboration with M. Tingley probed the common assumption of a linear relationship between proxies of past climates and the climate itself [4]. It developed a closed-form Bayes estimator for the conditional distribution of temperature given proxies values, and showed that it significantly outperformed traditional linear regression. However, it was found that if proxies values were mapped to a normal distribution prior to regressing, then the results were nearly as good. This is important because it means that paleoclimatologists can work with proxies that harbor a very nonlinear relationship to climate without having to develop taylor-made probability models for each dataset [4].

 

PI Emile-Geay also led a probabilistic synthesis of observations and models of El Niño -Southern Oscillation over the past 10,000 years (the Holocene) [5].  El Niño -Southern Oscillation (ENSO) is the leading pattern of year-to-year climate variability, with huge impacts worldwide, as seen in the 2015/2016 event. Yet very little is known about its sensitivity to external forcing. The synthesis allowed us to probe ENSO’s sensitivity to orbital forcing, revealing important reductions in ENSO variability throughout the interval, whose magnitude and timing bear little resemblance to those simulated by climate models, or to the putative driving force of these changes (equatorial insolation) - at odds with traditional explanations. The synthesis also allowed us to test the ``frequency entrainment hypothesis'', often invoked to explain the response of ENSO to orbital forcing. It showed that most models are consistent with this hypothesis, but observations are not.  The results suggests that tropical Pacific climate is highly variable, exhibiting long, quiescent periods without simple relation to external forcing. The existence of these periods questions the existing paradigm, highlighting a major gap in our understanding of a climate system of global importance.
